Jamal al-Harith - who was born Ronald Fiddler and raised in Moss Side - detonated a car bomb at an army base near Mosul earlier this week, killing an unknown number of Shiite Muslims Share Jamal al-Harith - who was born Ronald Fiddler (Photo: Handout) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! A British terrorist who carried out a deadly suicide bombing in Iraq was a Manchester convert to Islam who appears to have hoodwinked his family and supporters into believing he was an innocent traveling through Muslim countries to teach English. 
Jamal al-Harith - who was born Ronald Fiddler and raised in Moss Side - detonated a car bomb at an army base near Mosul earlier this week, killing an unknown number of Shiite Muslims. 
He had been held captive at the maximum security Camp Delta at Guantanamo Bay in Cuba from 2001 after American troops had arrested him in Kandahar for allegedly fighting alongside the Taliban against British and US troops in Afghanistan. 
The web designer protested his innocence - claiming he was in Afghanistan to teach English - and his case was championed by furious civil rights groups and the Tony Blair Government, who campaigned for his release. Jamal al-Harith was raised in Moss Side and attended Ducie High School and Wythenshawe Technical College 
Islamic State fighter with links to Manchester 'carries out suicide bombing in Iraq' 
The former Ducie High School pupil claimed he was a tourist who was being held by the Taliban as a British spy when the Americans moved into Kandahar. 
His father Lloyd Fiddler said at the time: “It breaks my heart and I am praying for him. I don’t know what I can do to help him. He’s not what they think he is.” 
The website designer was named Ronald Otis Fiddler by his Jamaican parents Lloyd and Joyce when he was born in 1965, the third of four children. 
After Ducie, he moved to Wythenshawe Technical College where he had many Muslim friends. He converted to Islam when he was 25 and later went to the Sudan to learn Arabic. 
The then Manchester Central MP Tony Lloyd - now the Police and Crime Commissioner - called his ongoing detention a ‘disgrace’ and called on the authorities to release or charge him. Iraqi security forces advance on the southern outskirts of Mosul, Iraq, Tuesday, Feb. 21, 2017. A military spokesman says Iraqi forces are consolidating their gains south of Mosul ahead of moving deeper into the city's Islamic State-held western half. The spokesman of the Joint Military Operation Command, Brig. Gen. Yahya Rasool, told The Associated Press that nearly 123 square kilometers -- about 47 square miles -- have been taken south of Mosul since the new push started on Sunday. (AP Photo/Mohammed Saad) Read More Mum releases harrowing pictures of baby son - showing him just moments before he died from meningitis 
Al-Harith was eventually released after two years in captivity in 2004 - claiming he had been tortured - and is reported to have successfully claimed £1m in compensation after alleging British agents knew or were complicit in his treatment. 
Earlier this week, the so-called Islamic State terror group released a picture of a grinning al-Harith, 50, sitting inside what appears to be his car bomb moments before his Mosul attack. 
His brother, Leon Jameson, told The Times Al-Harith had ‘wasted his life’. 
He added: “I didn’t think he’d ever do anything wrong but, if he’s joining extremists, then, you know ... I’m not ashamed of him, I never will be. But it’s his own decision. I can only just give him advice if he needs any.” 
The 53-year-old said his brother had been a keen sportsman in his youth, playing football, basketball and table-tennis and winning a trophy for karate when he was a teenager. Jamal al-Harith pictured inside the car bomb which was detonated at an army base near Mosul Read More Teenage yob banned from Metrolink after commuter 'Super Juan' abused on tram 
He maintained his brother had been ‘dragged into’ radical Islam. 
Documents released by Wikileaks in 2011 show how Al-Harith was recommended for release in September, 2002. Major General Michael Dunlavey concluded he ‘was not affiliated to al-Qaeda or a Taliban leader’. 
Despite the conclusion, Al-Harith remained in custody for a further 18 months. 
But a later ruling signed by Major General Geoffrey D Miller in July, 2003, overturned the original assessment, insisting ‘this detainee possesses a high threat to the US, its interests and allies’. 
It was unclear why the assessment was later changed again, prompting Al-Harith’s release in March, 2004. 
The document outlined US fears about their detainee. 
It said he was ‘probably involved in a former terrorist attack against the US’ although it does not give details. He was held captive at Guantanamo Bay after being arrested in Afghanistan in 2001 - but he protested his innocence claiming he was in Afghanistan to teach English (Photo: Getty) Read More Footballer 'performed sex acts with girl he groomed' after meeting at school tournament, court hears 
The document says he was with a named ‘well-known Al-Qaeda operative’ in Sudan in 1992 when, it is suggested, Osama Bin Laden was also active in the country. 
While in Guantanamo, he was overheard talking about how food he had just eaten reminded him of a restaurant in Jedda, Saudi Arabia, even though he had told his interrogators he had never been to Saudi, according to the document. 
A school Al-Harith said he attended in Sudan ‘did not exist’ although there was a terror training camp there, it says. 
British Embassy officials on the ground in Afghanistan, according to the document, said Al-Harith appeared to be the leader of a group of five political prisoners released when western troops moved in Afghanistan. The British concluded he was ‘cocky and evasive’, it continues. 
The document also says Al-Harith failed a lie-detector test in April, 2003. He was asked whether he had links with extremists or whether he had gone to Afghanistan for Jihad – to wage holy war. 
“He answered ‘no’ to both questions and was found deceptive each time,” according to the assessment. Like us on Facebook
